Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Systematics and evolutionary history of the southern redback salamander: using next generation sequencing with organisms with large genomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The southeastern United States is a hotspot for amphibian biodiversity, but many amphibian species in the region are undergoing rapid declines. This is especially true for salamanders, which are incredibly diverse in the Southeast. Examining genetic relationships, climate factors, and changes in geographic distributions can increase our understanding of the complex mechanisms influencing the generation and decline of species. The goals of this project are to combine data from new methods of DNA sequencing with geographic and environmental data, in order to test hypotheses about evolutionary relationships of the southern redback salamander and changes in its geographic distribution through time.

Salamanders have genomes approximately 10 times larger than humans, and this large genome size can pose problems for new DNA sequencing methods. This project will test the utility of a newly established DNA sequencing protocol in resolving evolutionary relationships for species with large genomes. This research will be the first study to use a next-generation DNA sequencing technique to generate a genome-wide data set of 400-800 million DNA sequence fragments for a species. Results from this study will inform salamander conservation, amphibian systematics, and evolutionary biogeography more generally, as well as the future of systematics studies of organisms with large genomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the work on this project assessed the genetic diversity of the salamander Plethodon serratus within and among the five geographically isolated regions of its geographic range in the southeastern US. Understanding how populations are related to each other is essential for designing the most effective and efficient management strategies for species of conservation concern such as Plethodon serratus. Effectively investigating these questions requires a large genetic data set comprising hundreds to thousands of DNA sequences for each individual salamander. But salamanders have huge genomes, which pose problems for many of the new DNA sequencing methods. Because of this hurdle, salamanders had not been studied as intensively using new groundbreaking genetics methods as other organisms.

This project was one of the first studies to demonstrate that these new methods of easily sequencing millions of loci (approximately "genes") are, in fact, effective and appropriate for use with salamanders, even without modifying the standard laboratory steps. This is important because modifying laboratory protocols requires time and money for trial and error. While progress in methodology is certainly critical in the field of biology, equally important is the fact that in the meantime, the current methods can be used in genetic studies of salamanders of urgent conservation concern with reduced hesitation from fear that high-quality data would not be obtainable.

We generated and analyzed a DNA sequence data set of >1,000 loci per salamander for approximately 200 Plethodon serratus salamanders. Our data show that Plethodon serratus salamanders from one site in Louisiana are more closely related to salamanders in the western Ouachita Mountains than to salamanders at the other Louisiana site. Our data also suggest that the species currently recognized as Plethodon serratus may actually contain multiple "cryptic" species – or species that look very similar but are genetically very different from each other. In addition to genetics, we used computer modeling with climate data to study how the geographic range of Plethodon serratus has changed through time. Our data suggest the species range was broadly distributed across the Southeast during periods with cooler climates and has since contracted and fragmented its range in response to a warming climate.

More broadly, the genus Plethodon has a history of genome size expansions and contractions. Within the eastern Plethodon, the lineage that includes Plethodon serratus has undergone genome size contraction. Conversely, the western Plethodon lineage has undergone genome size expansion since divergence from the eastern Plethodon.

A secondary part of this project was the development of a new method for quantifying the extent of fragmentation of a species geographic range – for example, on a continuum from completely contiguous, to extremely patchy. This new tool will be an important addition to the field of biology – particularly to studies of how and why species ranges change over time, including predicting how the extent of fragmentation of a species range may change in the future due to various factors such as climate change and habitat destruction.

This project gave me (Co-PI) the opportunity to learn new bioinformatics (computational) methods for analyzing large DNA sequencing genetic data sets, including coding, implementing software pipelines, and using the LSU High Performance Computing (HPC) system and the HPC system of the Louisiana Optical Network Infrastructure. I also attended a workshop on conservation genomics, learning ways to apply genomics methods to species of special concern such as Plethodon serratus. In addition, this project allowed me to participate in numerous local community outreach events in southeast Louisiana. These events are designed to educate children and adults about natural history museum collections, collections-based research, Louisiana biodiversity, and specific ongoing research at the LSU Museum of Natural Science – including this project, which concerns a Louisiana salamander listed as Critically Imperiled (Plethodon serratus). I have presented results from this project at numerous regional, national, and international conferences and invited seminars, and I continue to present results from this project to undergraduate and graduate students during lecture in relevant courses I teach.
